bill_title: prohibit computer damage, computer theft, and unauthorized computer access and provide penalties therefor.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to prohibit computer damage, computer theft, and unauthorized computer access and provide penalties therefor. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. Terms used in this Act mean: (1) "Access," to instruct, communicate with, store data in, or retrieve data from a computer, computer system, or computer network; (2) "Authorization," the permission of the owner of the computer, computer system, computer network, computer software, or other property. The owner may limit the authorization by: (a) Giving the user actual notice orally or in writing; (b) Posting a written notice in a prominent location adjacent to the computer being used; or (c) Using a notice displayed on or announced by the computer being used; (3) "Computer," an electronic device which performs logical, arithmetic or memory functions by the manipulations of signals, including but not limited to electronic or magnetic impulses; (4) "Computer system," related, connected or unconnected, computers and peripheral equipment; (5) "Computer network," means the interconnection of a communication system with a computer through a remote terminal, or with two or more interconnected computers or computer systems, and includes private and public telecommunications networks; (6) "Property," includes, but it not limited to, electronically processed or produced data and information contained in a computer or computer software in either machine or human readable form; (7) "Services," includes but is not limited to, computer time, data processing, and storage functions; (8) "Computer program," an instruction or statement or a series of instructions or statements, in a form acceptable to a computer, which directs the functioning of a computer system in a manner designed to provide appropriate products from the computer; (9) "Computer software," a computer program or procedures, or associated documentation concerned with the operation of a computer; (10) "Loss," the greatest of the following: (a) The retail market value of the property or services involved; (b) The reasonable repair or replacement cost, whichever is less; or (c) The reasonable value of the damage created by the unavailability or lack of utility of the property or services involved until repair or replacement can be effected; (11) "Computer security system," a software program or computer device that is intended to protect the confidentially and secrecy of data and information stored in or accessible through the computer system; (12) "Destructive computer program," computer program that performs a destructive function or produces a destructive product. A program performs a destructive function if it degrades performance of the affected computer, associated peripherals or a computer program; disables the computer, associated peripherals or a computer program; or destroys or alters computer programs or data. A program produces a destructive product if it produces unauthorized data, including data that make computer memory space unavailable; results in the unauthorized alteration of data or computer programs; or produces a destructive computer program, including a self-replicating computer program; (13) "Encryption," any protective or disruptive measure, including but not limited to, cryptography, enciphering, or encoding that: (a) Causes or makes any data, information, image, program, signal, or sound unintelligible or unusable; or (b) Prevents, impedes, delays, or disrupts access to any data, information, image, program, signal, or sound. (14) "Personal data," any computer property or computer program which contains records of the employment, salary, credit, or other financial or personal information relating to another person. Section 2. Any person who does any of the following is guilty of computer damage and may be sentenced as provided in section 3 of this Act: (1) Intentionally and without authorization damages or destroys any computer, computer system, computer network, computer software, or any other property specifically defined in section 1 of this Act; (2) Intentionally and without authorization or with intent to injure or defraud alters any computer, computer system, computer network, computer software, or any other property specifically defined in section 1of this Act; or (3) Distributes a destructive computer program, without authorization and with intent to damage or destroy any computer, computer system, computer network, computer software, or any other property specifically defined in section 1 of this Act. Section 3. Any person who commits computer damage may be sentenced as follows: (1) To imprisonment for not more than ten years or to payment of a fine of not more than fifty thousand dollars, or both, if the damage, destruction or alteration results in a loss in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars, to the owner, or the owner's agent, or lessee: (2) To imprisonment for not more than five years or to payment of a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars, or both, if the damage, destruction or alteration results in a loss of more than five hundred dollars, but not more than two thousand five hundred dollars to the owner, or the owner's agent or lessee; or (3) In all other cases to imprisonment for not more than ninety days or to payment of a fine of not more than one thousand dollars, or both. Section 4. Any person who does any of the following is guilty of computer theft and may be sentenced as provided in section 5 of this Act: (1) Intentionally and without authorization or claim of right accesses or causes to be accessed any computer, computer system, computer network or any part thereof for the purpose of obtaining services or property; or (2) Intentionally and without claim of right, and with intent to deprive the owner of use or possession, takes, transfers, conceals or retains possession of any computer, computer system, or any computer software or data contained in a computer system, or computer network. Section 5. Any person who commits computer theft may be sentenced as follows: (1) To imprisonment for not more than ten years or to payment of a fine of not more than fifty thousand dollars, or both, if the loss to the owner, or the owner's agent, or lessee is in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars; or (2) To imprisonment for not more than five years or to payment of a fine of not more than ten thousand dollars, or both, if the loss to the owner, or the owner's agent, or lessee is more than five hundred dollars but not more than two thousand five hundred dollars; or (3) In all other cases to imprisonment for not more than ninety days or to payment of a fine of not more than one thousand dollars, or both. Section 6. A person is guilty of unauthorized computer access if the person intentionally and without authorization attempts to or does penetrate a computer security system. (1) A person who violates this section in a manner that creates a grave risk of causing the death of a person is guilty of a felony and may be sentenced to imprisonment for not more than ten years or to payment of a fine of not more than twenty thousand dollars, or both. (2) A person who is convicted of a second or subsequent gross misdemeanor violation of this section is guilty of a felony and may be sentenced under paragraph (1). Section 7. A person who violates section 6 of this Act in a manner that creates a risk to public health and safety is guilty of a gross misdemeanor and may be sentenced to imprisonment for a term of not more than one year or to payment of a fine of not more than three thousand dollars, or both. (1) A person who violates section 6 of this Act and gains access to personal data is guilty of a gross misdemeanor and may be sentenced under this section. (2) A person who is convicted of a second or subsequent misdemeanor violation of section 6 of this Act within five years is guilty of a gross misdemeanor and may be sentenced under this section. Section 8. A person who violates section 6 of this Act is guilty of a misdemeanor and may be sentenced to imprisonment for a term of not more than ninety days or to payment of a fine of not more than one thousand dollars or both.

action_log.status_text: First read in House and referred to
